p:
Eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA, 20:5 ω-3) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA; 22:6 ω-3) are the major ω-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) found in fish oils
13, 14 . These fatty acids are found in skin in low concentrations, especially in individuals consuming a Western diet characterized by high amounts of ω-6 over ω-3 PUFA sources
14, 15 . Increased ω-3 PUFA intake leads to the incorporation of these fatty acids into phospholipids of cell membranes
16 and, the consequent accumulation of metabolites derived from them in the epidermis which explains the beneficial effects of ω-3 fatty acids in cutaneous inflammation, such as psoriasis
17 .
